text:
Tenth Ave., south from, but not including West 30th Street. This view is as seen from the pedestrian bridge, at West 30th Street.

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Tenth Ave., at the S.E. corner of West 30th Street. Shown is the 30th Street Station of the N.Y. Central and Hudson River R.R. Co.
May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same site, at a later date, but viewed westward. Site will be used by the U.S. Post Office, for a parcel post station.
April 9, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

P. L. Sperr.

343 Tenth Ave., at the S.W. corner of West 30th Street, formerly the Hudson Exchange Hotel. Also shown is a portion of the pedestrian bridge across "Railroad Ave".

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Eleventh Avenue, south from a point slightly above West 30th Street, showing prominently the pedestrian bridge over the Avenue at that thoroughfare. This was erected by the New York Central Railroad because of the danger involved by the use of the street bed by their trains. Popularly this was called "Death Avenue". To the left are the milk shed yards .

May 17, 1927

(1)
Tenth Ave., west side, north from, but not including West 30th to, but not including 31st Streets. The view shows the yards of the N. Y. Central and Hudson River R.R. Company.

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same.

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

May 17, 1927.

(2)
The same.

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

30th Street, adjoining and west of the north west corner of Tenth Avenue, showing part of the New York Central yards in the right background. In the foreground, crossing the sidewalk, is the boy on horseback who rides ahead of the engine on Tenth Avenue.

May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

A general view of the midtown Manhattan-West Side section of the City, showing the New York Central Railroad yards west of Tenth Avenue above W. 30th Street, as photographed from the 15 story loft building at No. 406-26 W. 31st St. The tenements in the center foreground are at the N.W. corner of Tenth Avenue and 31st Street. In the background is Hudson River and its Jersey shoreline.

About 1929

Ewing Galloway
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West side.

text:
Milk sheds and New York Central Station, 30th Street, at, and adjoining the S.E. corner of Tenth Avenue, as seen through the bridge over the New York Central lines.

May 12, 1930.

P.L. Sperr.

30th Street, north side, east from No. 527 West 30th, between Eleventh and Tenth Avenues.

September 18, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

30th Street, east from No. 529 and 526 West 30th, between Eleventh and Tenth Avenues. The bridge at Tenth Avenue runs from the northeast corner to the southwest corner.

September 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

541, 533-529, 527-507 West 30th Street, north side, between Eleventh and Tenth Avenues and towards Tenth.

September 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same scene two years later, after demolition of the buildings on 30th Street to make room for the New York Central elevated roadbed.
In the background behind the Runkel plant, notice the tower of the Empire State Building.

July 9, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Tenth Ave., west side, (street walk not shown) at West 30th Street. On the left appears West 30th Street, south side, west from, but not including Tenth Ave. The view shows the yards and tracks of the N. Y. Central and Hudson R.R. Company.

January 28, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

August 25, 1940

West 30th Street, north side, west from Tenth Avenue, showing the elevated roadbed carrying the New York Central tracks around this yard. View 2 is photographed from Eleventh Avenue.

August 25, 1940
